Available in French REASONS FOR DECISION

OVERVIEW

[1] The Appellant, Veroni[REDACTED], is a citizen of Trinidad and Tobago. She

became a permanent resident of Canada in 2012. After landing in Canada, the A ppellant stayed

here for about two months. She returned to Trinidad and Tobago to wrap up her affairs. Later, her

parents became ill, which prevented her from retuning back to Canada sooner.

[2] In 2020, the Appellant applied for a Permanent Resident Travel D ocument to return to

Canada, but the visa officer refused her application. The Appellant did not respect her residency

obligations to be present in Canada in the relevant five -year period for at least 730 days.1 In the

relevant five -year period, she was pr esent for only 136 days.

[3] The Appellant appealed the visa officer’s decision to the Immigration Appeal Division. She

admitted that the visa officer ’s decision is l...

RAD File No. / N° de dossier de la S AR :





REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the Appellant) is a citizen of Saint Lucia. She appeals a decision of the

Refugee Protection Division (RPD) denying her claim for refugee protection. The Appellant asks

the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) to set aside the decision of the RPD, and find the Appellant

to be a Convention refugee, or in the alternative, refer the claim back to the RPD for

redetermination. The Appellant asks for a hearing to deal with the documentation presented in the

Memorandum of Appeal. No new evidence was presented in the Me morandum of Appeal.

DETERMINATION

[2] Pursuant to ss. 111(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), the RAD

confirms the determination of the RPD and dismisses the appeal.

Background

[3] The Appellant was raised by her stepmother, and does not ha ve any knowledge of her

biological mother. The Appellant discovered during her teenage years that she was more attracted

to girls than boys. As a result of the homophobic attitudes in Saint Lucia, the [REDACTED] became

withdrawn and unhappy emotionally. The Appellant ...

IAD File No / No. Dossier de la SAI : MA1-03234 Client ID / No ID Client : 2596-5786 1

Oral Reasons for Decision

[1] This is the decision in the appeal by [REDACTED] (the appellant) from a deportation order made against him on November 16, 2000 following his conviction for trafficking narcotics on April 26, 1996 where he received a sentence of 3 years’ imprisonment. [2] This deportation order was stayed by the Immigrat ion Appeal Division’s Member [REDACTED] on December 10, 2001. At that time, following a recommendation by the Minister’s counsel and taking into account different humanitarian and compassionate factors, Member [REDACTED] concluded that such a stay was warranted. I will quote from th e Member’s decision on page 2.

REASONS FOR DECISION



[1] These are the reasons and decision of the Immigration Appeal Division (the “IAD”)

pertaining to the appeal filed pursuant to subsection 63(1) of the Immigration and Refugee

Protection Act (the “ Act ”)1 made by [REDACTED] (the “appellant”), from the refusal of the

sponsorship application for a permanent resident visa of her spouse, Jam[REDACTED]

(the “applicant”) from Afghanistan.



[2] The application was refused under subsection 4(1) of the Immigration and Refugee

Protection Regulations (the “ Regulations ”)2 and subsection 16(1) of the Act . The details of the

refusal are set out in the refusal letter and C AIPS3 notes of the immigration officer.4



BACKGROUND



[3] The appellant is 52 years old and was landed in Canada in April 1984. The applicant is 37

years old and lives in Afghanistan. The appellant and applicant were married on May 12, 2009.5



ANALYSIS



[4] Two t ests may be applied in order to disqualify a spouse under subsection 4(1) of the

Regulations. Only one of the tests must be satisfied if an applicant is to be disqualified as a

spous...

REASONS FOR DECISION



[1] These are my reasons and decision in the appeal of [REDACTED] (the

“appellan t”). The appeal is from a refusal to approve the permanent resident visa applications

made by Syl[REDACTED] and Ja[REDACTED] (the “applicants”) who

were sponsored by the appellant. Those are the appellant's biological parents.



[2] The abili ty to sponsor family members is permitted by sections 12 and 13 of the

Immigra tion and Refugee Protection Act (the “ Act ”).1 Eligibility to sponsor requires

demonstration of income at, or above, income levels that are set by the Immigration and Refugee

Prot ection R egulation s (the “ Regulations ”).2



[3] This application was refused based on an assessment of income from December 2012, to

December 2013, for five persons. At that time, the sponsor had to show income at, or above, the

levels established by regulation , which for five persons was $46,850.



[4] The regulation setting out the requirement is 133(1)(j)(1) of the Regulat...

[1] Madam, I have considered your testimony and the other evidence in the case and I am

ready to render my decision orally. A written form of the reasons will be provided to you and

your counsel shortly. The written form may be edited for spelling, syntax and grammar and

references to the applicable case law an d documentary evidence may also be included.

[2] This is the decision of the refugee protection division in the claim of [REDACTED] , a citizen of the Federal Republic of Nigeria by birth and a citizen of the Commonwealth

of Grenada by naturalization, who s eeks refugee protection pursuant to section 96 and subsection

97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act1 (IRPA) .

ALLEGATIONS

[3] Ms. [REDACTED] , you allege that you are bi -sexual . Y ou allege that you fear persecution for

reasons of your membership in a pa rticular social group, namely your sexual orientation in

Grenada and Nigeria. You allege made a radio broadcast supporting homosexuality in Grenada;

fearing for your life you fled to Canada where you made a claim for protection nine months after

your arriv al in this country.

DETERMINATION

REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the Appellant) and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the minor Appellant),

who claim to be citizens of Somalia, appeal a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

denying their claims for refugee protection. They have submitted new evidence in support of their

claims and they have requested an oral hearing. The Appellants further request that the Refugee

Appeal Division (RAD) find that they are Convention refugees. Alternatively the Appellants

request that the matter be remitted to the RPD for reconsideration by a differently -constituted

panel.

DETE RMINATION

[2] Pursuant to section 111(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), The

RAD sets aside the determination of the RPD and substitutes its decision that t he Appellants are

Convention re fugees. The appeals are allowed.

[1] This is the decision in the application from the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration

Canada ( the “ Applicant ”) pursuant to Section 108 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection

Act (the “ Act ”).1



[2] The application from Minister of Citizenship and Immigration Canada is to cessate the

refugee status of [REDACTED] , a citizen of Iran. A hearing into this application was

held on August 13, 2014.



[3] The Respondent was present at the hearing with her Counsel. The Minister’s

representative was also present at the hearing.





PRELIMINARY MATTERS



[4] Counsel for the Respondent made an application at the hearing held on August 13, 2014

to change the date an d time of the hearing (CDT). Counsel explained that he had made an

Access to Information and Privacy (ATIP) request to the Department of Citizenship and

Immigration Canada (CIC). Counsel explained that he expected a response to his ATIP request

within 30 days.

RAD F ile No. / N° de dossier de la SA R :

REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , (the Appellant), a citizen of Somalia, appeals a decision of the

Refugee Protection Division (RPD) denying his claim for refugee protection. He has submitted

new evidence in support of his appeal. The Appellant asks the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) to

overturn the negative decision of the RPD and replace it with a positive finding on the

Appellant’s behalf or in the alternative to refer the matter back to the RPD for re -determination.

DETERMINATION

[2] Pursuant to Section 111(1)(b) of the Immigration an d Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), the

RAD sets aside the determination of the RPD and substitutes its determination that the Appellant

is a Convention refugee.

BACKGROUND

[3] The Appellant alleged before the RPD that, as a 29 year old born in Abu Dhabi (United

Arab Emirates – U.A.E.) to Somali parents, he has no right of abode in the U.A.E. and has never

been to Somalia where he is a citizen because of his birth parents. The Appellant fears that he will

be targeted by the terrorist group, Al Shabaab, a group whi ch he allege...

family are staunch Christians who believe that homosexuality i...

protection. The Appellants request that the RPD review and reverse the RPD ’s decision and find

matter back to the RPD for re -determination.

[2] The minor daughter of the Appellant submitted a B asis of Claim (BOC) narrative

translated and written by his mother. The minor son of the Appellant relies on her mother’s BOC

narrative. The mother was the Designated Representative for the minor Appellants.
